workflow.name: Handle Gmail reply-based scheduling with Google Calendar and GPT-4o-mini
workflow.description:
Reply Handling (Optional Extension)

This optional workflow handles email replies after availability options have been sent.

It extends the main scheduling flow by enabling two-way, email-based confirmation.

What this extension does

Listens for user replies via Gmail

Normalizes free-text replies into structured data

Detects whether the user confirmed a proposed slot or requested alternatives

Automatically creates a Google Calendar event on confirmation

Sends a confirmation or follow-up email accordingly

Why this matters

Most scheduling automations stop after sending availability.
This extension closes the loop by turning email replies into real actions ‚Äî
without requiring booking links or manual follow-ups.

Typical reply examples

1 ‚Üí Confirms the suggested time and creates the calendar event

2 ‚Üí Requests alternative time slots and continues the scheduling flow

When to use this

Email-first scheduling (no Calendly / booking pages)

High-touch or human-like scheduling flows

Sales calls, interviews, consultations, internal meetings

assignments.name: text
assignments.value:
Meeting in Shibuya on December 28 from 7:00 to 8:00 PM.

values.content:
You are an assistant that extracts structured calendar event data.

Return ONLY valid JSON in the following format:
{
  "title": string,
  "start_datetime": string (ISO 8601),
  "end_datetime": string (ISO 8601),
  "location": string,
  "attendees": [string],
  "description": string
}

Do not include any extra text.

=Extract calendar event details from the text below.

Return JSON with:
- title
- start_datetime (ISO 8601)
- end_datetime (ISO 8601)
- location
- attendees (array of emails)
- description

Text:
{{ $json.text }}

parameters.content:
## üìÖ Smart Calendar Scheduling Workflow

What this workflow does:
This workflow automatically checks Google Calendar availability and either creates a new event or sends a notification email if the time slot is already booked.

How it works:
1. The workflow is triggered via a Webhook.
2. Input data such as title, start time, and end time is prepared.
3. Google Calendar availability is checked for the requested time slot.
4. If the time is available, a calendar event is created automatically.
5. If the time is not available, an email notification is sent instead.

When it is used:
This workflow is used when scheduling meetings automatically without manual calendar checks.

Who benefits:
Anyone who wants to automate meeting scheduling, avoid double bookings, and save time using Google Calendar.

## Trigger & Input
Trigger & input layer.
Starts the workflow via webhook or test input.
Provides initial data to the system.

## AI & Data Preparation 
AI processing and data preparation.
Generates text and formats calendar payload.
Prepares clean scheduling data.

## Availability Decision 
Availability check and decision logic.
Checks if the time slot is free.
Routes the workflow based on the result.

## Final Action
Final action layer.
Creates a calendar event or sends a notification email.
Completes the workflow.

## Reply Handling (Optional Extension)
This section demonstrates how email replies can be handled
as an extension to the main scheduling workflow in production.

This workflow showcases an end-to-end,
email-based scheduling system.

It automatically:
- Checks calendar availability
- Sends alternative time slots if unavailable
- Listens for email replies
- Confirms and creates calendar events upon user confirmation

data.details:
The IF node can be used to implement binary conditional logic in your workflow. You can set up one-to-many conditions to evaluate each item of data being inputted into the node. That data will either evaluate to TRUE or FALSE and route out of the node accordingly.

This node has multiple types of conditions: Bool, String, Number, and Date & Time.
